comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content: This photograph was taken during the Irish Automobile club Reliability Trials in either 1906 or 1907. (I'll check which year in the contemporary records and advise later).

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75421485@N08] That would be absolutely excellent, thank you! Will wait to hear from you then...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content:
I have a postcard of this photograph and have always believed it to be of a car competing in one of the Irish Automobile Club's Irish Reliability Trials in the period 1906-1909. We have a large number of photographs of these events in the RIAC Archive. However, on looking at the enlarged version of this photograph, I'm not so sure. The two passengers front and back on the right hand side of the car are female and this does not tie in with a competitor in the Trials in which the two back seat passengers would have been male 'Observers'. 

Likewise the registration you give for this car - IC 2043 - does not appear to be correct. The Irish Motor Directory confirms that there were only 51 cars and 66 motorcycles registered in County Carlow by 1911 so this registration was still a long way from being issued. (I would suggest the car is 1907/8). More research needed!

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75421485@N08] "More research needed" is our mantra here! Just reading back through all of the many comments on this one, Bob. The reg. is definitely #C 2043. If the first letter was L rather than I, would that be an English reg. no., in which case we're back to the theory of English tourists? Or am I clutching at straws?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content: LC 2043 would make much more sense.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75421485@N08] Great, Bob, thanks.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 75421485@N08
comment._content: LC would appear to be a registration mark for Glamorganshire. While in all probability this is a touring group, many cars in Ireland carried index marks from mainland Britain.

comment.author: 60812213@N04
comment._content: The LC mark was for London, introduced in 1903. So 2043 would make it about 1906/7 when it was registered.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/75421485@N08] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/abandonedrailsireland] Found a PDF from Chiltern Vehicle Preservation Group that says that 1-2 letter plates followed by 1 to 4 number were "originally issued to vehicles first registered between 1903 and the mid 1930's." It goes on to say "LC - London North West (Greater London to 1974)" So we were right in finally arriving at 1906/07 then?
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 64555638@N00
comment._content: Still safe for the year, but I don't think the car is a Ford Model K as pictured. Radiator and bonnet are very different. The bodies would mainly have been coachbuilt in those days so from the firewall back may look the same as several other makes of cars.

comment.author: 34397115@N00
comment._content:
The tea-shop owner is probably my grandmother, Mary O’Connor (née O’Sullivan) who was born in 1880.  She married my grandfather in February 1905 and presumably moved to the Tunnel then.  Therefore a date from 1905 onwards is likely.  The photo appears to have been taken at the same time as those referenced in the collection as L_ROY_08674, L_ROY_08675 and L_ROY_03046.  Photo 08674 is almost identical, with a charabanc substituted for the car.  
Brendan Lyons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/34397115@N00] Thanks Brendan! Do you think that might be your grandmother standing by the door? Certainly your dating information is of great value. I can't remember if it was possible to read the notice outside the door, but I'll check on the super dooper hi res image to see if it gives any other information.
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 34397115@N00
comment._content: You're welcome.  Yes, I think that is she at the door.
